item.title: Post Election Reflection
item.description: Here is my post election reflection, using data available leading up to 11/23 at 8pm EST.

item.title: Final Prediction
item.description: Here is my final predicton model, using data available leading up to 11/7 at 4pm EST.

item.title: Shocks
item.description: Intro and Shocks Discussion Since Election Day is 13 days away, I will mainly focus this blog post on refining my current models at the nationwide and district level. However, I will also include a brief summary of this week’s topic, Shocks, as I think it is important in considering uncertainty in my models. Election shocks can be described as events that one couldn’t have forecasted but could significantly affect election outcomes.

item.title: Air War
item.description: In this post, I look at the effects of campaign ads on predicting US house elections through Extension

item.title: Incumbency
item.description: In this post, I explore expert electoral ratings, with a particular focus on Incumbency.

item.title: Polling
item.description: In this post, I look at the relationship between polling and US house voting patterns. I begin with an analysis of midterm forecasting methods from FiveThirtyEight and The Economist and end with a new model for predicting popular vote house share in 2022.

item.title: Blog Post #2 - Economy
item.description: In this post, I look at the relationship between economic forces and US house voting patterns at the state and national level. As a fundamental part of the campaign environment, the a strong economy can help an incumbent president maintain power in other chambers while a gloomy economy can make the case harder for incumbents.

item.title: Blog Post #1 - Introduction
item.description: In this post, I explore United States House races from 1948 to the present. I conduct the majority of my analysis through state-wide pooling with a special section at the end for the district I’ll be following, Ohio-01.
